Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Predictive Modeling of Construction Injuries in Complex Environments - An Integrated Research, Teaching and Outreach Plan

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) program award is to test the hypothesis that over half of the variability in construction injury statistics can be explained by a few inherent and basic attributes of construction environments. Predictor attributes will be identified by studying measurable patterns in US construction injury reports and the resulting dataset will be reduced to principal attributes using multivariate statistics. Principal attributes will be related to the probability of injury occurrence in mathematical models and the underlying hypothesis will be validated by comparing the predictions of these models with actual project outcomes. The teaching objectives are to incorporate new research knowledge into experiential learning modules with videos, augmented reality, and building information models and to implement an original pedagogical and andragogical instruction strategy that involves collaborative multicultural industry-student teams.

If successful, the research results will enhance understanding of the fundamental causes of construction injuries and allow for accurate risk forecasts, directly addressing a critical societal concern that affects approximately six percent of the US workforce. Robust and valid predictive models will facilitate the integration safety risk analysis into emerging visualization and simulation technologies. Such integration may drastically improve proactive hazard recognition, prioritization, and control of complex projects and allow safety to be objectively considered as a competing criterion during design and planning. Educational and outreach activities will involve the development of research-based software tools that will be shared with industry stakeholders and students at high school, undergraduate, and graduate levels. The project places strong emphasis on outreach to the Hispanic community through recruitment of Hispanic research assistants and involvement of Hispanic industry leaders who will serve as student mentors and agents for research dissemination.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project tested the hypothesis that over half of the variability in construction injury statistics can be explained by inherent and basic attributes of construction environments. Predictor attributes were initially identified through manual content analysis of text descriptions of approximately 500 past construction injuries. Manual analysis was used to train natural language processing algorithms that were later applied to automatically analyze approximately 5,000 additional reports. This process converted previously unused text into a structured numerical database of suitable size for machine learning. Algorithms were created and validated that were capable of predicting the type of injury, body part injured, energy source, and quantity of risk for new observations, thereby confirming the primary hypothesis. Unexpectedly, we found that the frequency-magnitude distribution of construction safety risk to be very similar to that of many natural phenomena such as precipitation or earthquakes. One of the implications is that like natural phenomena, construction safety may benefit from being studied quantitatively by leveraging empirical data rather than strictly being approached through a managerial perspective using subjective data, which is the current industry standard.

After the predictive modeling, unsupervised machine learning and network analysis were used to identify incompatibilities in attributes, allowing construction accidents to be modeled as perturbations in underlying networks of attributes. Injury severity could not be predicted using the fundamental attributes; however, later research revealed that severity can be accurately predicted by assessing the quantity of kinetic or potential energy present in the work environment.

As a part of the teaching plan, the research results were used to visualize safety risk in building information models and augmented reality education modules. These educational products were incorporated into one graduate and two undergraduate courses and were delivered in combined industry-student teams. The results were enhanced knowledge of safety planning for students and improved ability to assess risk and predict outcomes for industry professionals. The project placed strong emphasis on outreach to the Hispanic community through recruitment of Hispanic research assistants and involvement of Hispanic industry leaders who served as student mentors and agents for research dissemination.
